attributes.title: The role of communicative context in word learning
attributes.description: Our study investigates whether social cognition is related with the word learning process and the meaning retention outcome. In particular, we ask 1) whether individuals’ Theory of Mind ability is associated with word meaning acquired through pragmatic inference, 2) whether words learned through active pragmatic inference are better retained compared to words learned through paired association, and 3) whether pre-activating theory-of-mind enhances meaning acquisition through pragmatic inference.

q1.value: The role of communicative context and pragmatic skills in word learning

q3.value:
Our study investigates whether social cognition is related with the word learning process and the meaning retention outcome. In particular, we ask 1) whether individuals’ Theory of Mind ability is associated with word meaning acquired through pragmatic inference, 2) whether words learned through active pragmatic inference are better retained compared to words learned through paired association, and 3) whether pre-activating theory-of-mind enhances meaning acquisition through pragmatic inference.

The relationship between social cognition skills and meaning acquisition will significantly deepen our understanding of the interface between cognition and language. Future research will investigate these issues in children.

q4.value:
Hypothesis A (pragmatic skills and retention for inferred words):
Participants that perform better in the Theory of Mind task and the Executive Function task  will show better learning of inferred meanings, measured by both immediate attainment and delayed retention. We will control for individuals’ executive function skills while investigating the specific role of social cognition in word learning.


Hypothesis B (taught vs inferred words):
Participants will show higher accuracy in recalling inferred words compared to taught words due to a more active meaning encoding process.


Hypothesis C (ToM activation network and learning):
If Theory of Mind skills are related with inferring novel word meanings, we expect that pre-activating the Theory of Mind network before the word learning task might facilitate learning. We will explore this hypothesis in Experiment 2 through task order manipulation (a group of participants will start with the ToM task before moving on to the word learning task)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Experiment 1 will investigate the relationship between social cognition and word learning from pragmatic inference. The experiment  starts with the word learning task in which participants are exposed to the novel words and their learning efficacy is immediately tested after each block of words (please refer to the experimental setting and structure section below for more details). Subsequently, participants will move on to the Theory of Mind task and the Executive Function task (randomized task order for each participant). At the end of the experiment, participants will complete a Meaning Retention task in which their retention of the novel word meanings is assessed.

Experiment 2 will investigate the causal relationship between social cognition and word learning from pragmatic inference. Similar to the design in Experiment 1, participants will perform three tasks: Theory of mind task, Executive function task, and word learning task. One key difference is that one group of participants will perform the Theory of Mind task before word learning, while the other group will perform the Executive function task before word learning.

Experimental setting and structure: 

For the word learning task, participants are told that they are playing an online language game with a virtual partner named Mary. Mary is visiting a toy store and she is going to describe to them some toys she wants or likes. Participants’ goal is to find which toy Mary is referring to. They are informed that Mary sometimes uses words that are not English, because she speaks a different language. After the learning phase is completed, participants will be asked to recall the objects in a multiple-choice test session.

The visual array that participants are exposed to during the word learning trials includes a table, facing the participants and two toys each time. Depending on whether the trial involves a novel word meaning that is being explicitly taught or a meaning that participants needs to infer, they see one dinosaur and one alien or two aliens or two dinosaurs, respectively. More details about the exact design and the content of the learning trials can be found below. 

This word learning task is comprised of three phases: a familiarization phase, a learning phase, an immediate testing phase, and a delayed recall phase approximately 5-6 minutes later.

Familiarization phase: Our word learning task starts with the familiarization phase in which participants are introduced to the two toys, the alien and the dinosaur that they will be seeing throughout the task. They are informed that these are two of Mary’s favorite toys about which she is going to talk, leading them to the two practice trials. Each of these two practice trials is meant to familiarize participants with the setting for the inferred and the taught trials and they involve familiar objects (e.g. guitar).

Learning Phase: Following the familiarization trials, participants move on to the learning phase. The learning phase consists of four blocks: a block of trials in which participants need to infer the novel word meaning (inferred trials), always followed by a block of trials testing those inferred meanings (immediate inferred test trials), a block of trials where participants are explicitly taught the novel word meaning (taught trials), that are also followed by a block testing those taught meanings (immediate taught test trials). Across participants, we counterbalanced the order in such a way that half of the participants start with the inferred trials and immediate inferred test trials while the other half start with the taught trials and immediate taught test trials.

Inferred Trials Block: In this block, participants see two identical toys on the table (either two aliens or two dinosaurs). Toy 1 is holding one object while Toy 2 is holding the same object that Toy 1 is holding and another new object. The side on which the toy is holding two objects is counterbalanced across trials. Participants hear Mary saying: “Look! I like/want this dinosaur! It is holding a mel!” followed by our narrator – a different voice from Mary’s – asking “Which toy does Mary like/want?” The underlined word is the novel word meaning participants need to infer and it is aimed to refer to the second, extra object that one of the toys is holding. After the question is asked, participants need to click on the toy that they believe Mary likes or wants.

Taught Trials Block: For the taught trials, participants see two different toys (an alien and a dinosaur) holding the same object. Participants hear Mary saying: “Look! I like/want this bink! It is on the dinosaur!” followed by our narrator – a different voice from Mary’s – asking “Which toy does Mary like/want?” Here, the underlined word is the novel word meaning that is being taught as there is only one novel object across both toys and therefore, there is no pragmatic inference for ambiguity resolution. After the question is asked, participants need to click on the toy, the alien or the dinosaur that they believe Mary likes or wants.

Each block has 8 unique trials corresponding to a novel word in each one, but repeated twice in the same block, resulting in 16 trials for each block. All trials are presented in a randomized order for each participant.

Test trials:
Participants see 4 objects they have seen before (in a 2x2 arrangement) and they hear a sentence asking “Which one is a X?” where X is one of the new words they were exposed to in the learning trials. After the audio is completed, they need to click on one of the 4 toys to proceed to the next trial.

For the immediate test phase, there are 8 trials in total, each testing one of the novel words of the immediately preceded learning block and they are presented in a randomized order across participants.

For the delayed retention phase, there are 16 testing trials corresponding to the 8 novel taught words and the 8 novel inferred words, presented in a randomized order.

All recorded sentences are normalized in terms of approximate duration and intensity. 
All novel words are monosyllabic. Within each word type category, novel words do not share the same vowels or onsets. 


Theory of Mind task
For our Theory of Mind task, we are using the latest, updated version of Mind in the Eyes by Baron-Cohen et al. 2001. There are 36 trials in total presented in a randomized order across participants. 

In each trial, participants are presented with pictures of eyes and four different words. They are asked to choose one word out of the four given choices that they think best describes what the person pictured in the photo was thinking or feeling.

The total duration of the task is approximately 2-3 minutes.

Executive function task
To measure participants’ executive function, we intend to use Flanker task (as available from the Gorilla Task Inventory - www.gorilla.sc; Anwyl-Irvine, Massonnié, Flitton, Kirkham & Evershed, 2019) which is used to assess the participants’ ability to suppress responses that are inappropriate in a particular context. The task is comprised of 36 trials, in each of which participants are presented with 5 fish, either looking all in the same direction or in different directions. Participants need to press the button that matches the direction towards which the fish in the middle is looking. Just before each trial, there is a fixation point in the middle of the screen at which participants need to look. There are three different durations for which the point remains on screen before the actual trial begins: 400ms, 800ms and 1200ms. Out of the 36 trials, there 12 trials for each fixation duration. All trials are randomly presented across participants.
The total duration of the task is about 2 minutes.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
i.	Pre-selection rules:

We are recruiting adult participants, within the age range of 18 to 35, that are monolingual native speakers of English. We define monolingual as participants not being exposed to a second language before the age of 5.
        

ii.	Indicate where, from whom and how the data will be collected: 
We will recruit adult participants within our specified age range that either attend the University of Delaware or that reside locally and are willing and consent to participate in our research.

Our study is designed on the experimental platform, Gorilla, a cloud software platform specifically geared for the behavioral sciences (www.gorilla.sc). Our recruitment will take place through one of the following options: 
a) sending a simple link generated by Gorilla directly to the participants (their participation is completely anonymous, with only a random ID number assigned to them, no link occurs between their email or name and their participation)
b) through linking our Gorilla study with SONA, the subject pool for Psychological and Brain Sciences at the University of Delaware, through which students earn course credit for their participation
c) the Linguistics and Cognitive Science research participation page (https://www.lingcogsci.udel.edu/research/research-participation) through which undergraduate students reach out to participate in studies and earn credit towards one of their classes .


iii.	Describe data collection termination rule:
Data collection will be terminated when we reach our desired sample size.

iv.	Exclusion Criteria
We will exclude data in the following cases:

1.	Participants with incomplete set of data (stopped responding at some point of the online tasks).
2.	Participants that do not pass the familiarization phase.

q13.value: We will need approximately 34 participants per experiment.

q14.value: Based on some preliminary data from a pilot study not included in these experiments, we used the correlation coefficient for the relationship between participants’ Theory of Mind score and their performance in successfully recalling inferred meaning to calculate the desired sample size to detect a significant relationship between the two variables. For 95% power with a correlation coefficient set at 0.52 and alpha level at 0.05, we would need 34 participants (GPower 3.1).

question.value: Manipulated Variable 1: Target Word Type to be learned: two levels (1. Inferred words 2. Taught words), manipulated within participants

Measured variable 1: immediate attainment: accuracy of referent identification in the immediate testing trials (how many inferred and taught words participants remembered immediately following their exposure to the novel meanings)

Measured variable 2: retention: number of inferred and taught words correctly remembered/identified in the retention testing trials

Measured variable 3: Theory of Mind task score (treated as a predictor)

Measured variable 4: Executive Function score (treated as a predictor)

For each of the measured variables 1 and 2, we will take the average of correct answers. This will result in each each participant having an average score for immediate learning for inferred words, an average score for immediate learning for taught words, an average score for retention of inferred words and an average score for retention of taught words.

For Measure variable 3, we are planning to use the number of correct answers out of the 36 total trials. 

For Measure 4, we are planning to calculate the difference of each participants' reaction time for congruent and incongruent trials.

Across all experiments, we will conduct a partial correlation for the ToM score controlled for Flanker task score with participants' immediate accuracy score and retention score.
We are also planning to conduct a mixed-effects regression with participants' accuracy as the dependent variable and condition (taught or inferred words) and session (immediate learning and retention) as our fixed predictors. Our model will also include random effects for participants and items.

q20.value:
For the immediate learning and retention tasks, correct responses (i.e. correct identification of the name of the target word in each trial) will be coded as 1 while incorrect responses are coded as 0. Subsequently, the average of each participant's score will serve as their accuracy score for these tasks.

For the Theory of Mind task, correct answers will be again coded as 1 and incorrect responses coded as 0. For this time, we will calculate the overall sum of their correct responses which will serve as their ToM score.

For the Flanker task (executive function task), we will calculate the difference between each participants' reaction times for congruent and incongruent trials and the result will serve as their executive function score.

q21.value:
We will use the standard p < .05 criteria for determining:
a) whether ToM and Flanker scores are correlated with participants' performance 
b) whether participants perform differently across word types (taught vs inferred words) and session types (immediate learning and retention) when we control for random effects for participant and individual trials variability

q22.value:
We will exclude data in the following cases:

1.	Participants with incomplete set of data (stopped responding at some point of the online tasks).
2.	Participants that do not pass the familiarization phase.

q23.value: If a participant has missing data, we will exclude them from the analysis.

The relationship between social cognition skills and meaning acquisition will significantly deepen our understanding of the interface between cognition and language. Future research will investigate these issues in children.

attributes.title: Will Dolphins Save the World? Russian Conversations about the Sacralization of the Beautiful
attributes.description:
In the monograph, through the method of ethical questioning, a special place of open scientific thinking in the development of national culture is revealed. On the one hand, culture is conceived as a determinant of personal self-determination, which forms a person as an elementary unit and measure of a value system, on the other hand, it is an object of theoretical reflection, a complex systematic phenomenon causing social changes and the course of history. The book is written for students of social and humanitarian disciplines, scientists, philosophers and educators.
В монографии посредством этического вопрошания раскрывается особое место открытого научного мышления в становлении отечественной культуры. С одной стороны, культура мыслится в качестве детерминанты личностного самоопределения, формирующей личность как элементарную единицу и мерило ценностной системы, с другой — является объектом теоретической рефлексии, сложным системным феноменом, обуславливающим социальные изменения и ход истории. Книга адресована студентам социальных и гуманитарных дисциплин, ученым, философам и педагогам.

summary.value:
This is the first book of the project Conversations on the Sacralization of the Beautiful.
In the monograph, through the method of ethical questioning, a special place of open scientific thinking in the development of national culture is revealed. On the one hand, culture is conceived as a determinant of personal self-determination, which forms a person as an elementary unit and measure of a value system, on the other hand, it is an object of
theoretical reflection, a complex systematic phenomenon causing social
changes and the course of history.
The book is written for students of social and humanitarian disciplines, scientists, philosophers and educators.

This is the first book of the project Conversations on the Sacralization of the Beautiful.
In the monograph, through the method of ethical questioning, a special place of open scientific thinking in the development of national culture is revealed. On the one hand, culture is conceived as a determinant of personal self-determination, which forms a person as an elementary unit and measure of a value system, on the other hand, it is an object of
theoretical reflection, a complex systematic phenomenon causing social
changes and the course of history.
The book is written for students of social and humanitarian disciplines, scientists, philosophers and educators.

summary.value: The overall goal of current study is to examine normative attitudes in Greek life at Albright College. The current study will inform theory-development and design for future investigations of dissent and group processes in Greek Life at Albright College. Therefore, the primary aim of the current study is to examine “baseline attitudes” that current members of Albright College fraternities and sororities hold toward five group-relevant issues: (1) snap bidding, (2) collaborative leadership, (3) academic excellence, (4) fines, and (5) emphasis on social functions. For each issue, respondents will provide a measure of their personal support for the issue, as well as perceived norms (i.e., how they perceive the rest of the group to feel) about the issue. Please see "2020-01-15 Preregistration.docx" for more information on design, materials, analyses, etc.

registration_responses.summary: The overall goal of current study is to examine normative attitudes in Greek life at Albright College. The current study will inform theory-development and design for future investigations of dissent and group processes in Greek Life at Albright College. Therefore, the primary aim of the current study is to examine “baseline attitudes” that current members of Albright College fraternities and sororities hold toward five group-relevant issues: (1) snap bidding, (2) collaborative leadership, (3) academic excellence, (4) fines, and (5) emphasis on social functions. For each issue, respondents will provide a measure of their personal support for the issue, as well as perceived norms (i.e., how they perceive the rest of the group to feel) about the issue. Please see "2020-01-15 Preregistration.docx" for more information on design, materials, analyses, etc.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

other.value:
We will conduct a manipulation check question at Time 1 using these three items (1=Strongly disagree, 5=Strongly agree): Members of my group express continual disapproval of ideas; Members of my group show enthusiasm for the conversation; Members of my group help and encourage other members. 

Before beginning each brainstorming task participants will be asked a comprehension check question, “What are you and your group brainstorming?” and will select one of three options: “pasta/cereal name,” “event planning,” “the best science project.” 

Gender, age, ethnicity, and race are collected as demographics and are exploratory

sample.value: N=1000 participants from MTurk. Due to the data collection process on Amazon's Mechanical Turk, it is possible that we will collect slightly more than 1000; then with exclusions (see previous section) we may have a slightly smaller sample.

analyses.value:
We will regress intention to voice onto time, condition, and an interaction between time and condition using a multilevel model with repeated measures.
We will use an independent sample t-test to compare amplification and control conditions at Time 2

outliers.value: We will delete data from any duplicate IP addresses and any duplicate worker IDs.

dependent.value: Intention to voice will be measured at 2 time points using 6 items: Develop and make recommendations to the group concerning issues that affect the organization; Speak up and encourage group members to get involved in issues that affect the organization; Communicate your opinions about work issues to group members even if your opinion is different and others disagree with you; Keep well informed about issues where your opinion might be useful; Get involved in issues that affect the quality of work life in the organization; Speak up with ideas for new projects or changes in procedures.

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to either the amplification or control condition.

hypothesis.value: Can amplification increase intention to voice in a group with uncivil interactions?

The mistake was realized and, approximately an hour after the study was posted, we paused data collection to preregister the study. According to TurkPrime we collected 54 responses before data was paused. We have not examined the data.

registration_responses.data: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.
registration_responses.name: ACT-Uncivil Chat (2)
registration_responses.other:
We will conduct a manipulation check question at Time 1 using these three items (1=Strongly disagree, 5=Strongly agree): Members of my group express continual disapproval of ideas; Members of my group show enthusiasm for the conversation; Members of my group help and encourage other members. 

Before beginning each brainstorming task participants will be asked a comprehension check question, “What are you and your group brainstorming?” and will select one of three options: “pasta/cereal name,” “event planning,” “the best science project.” 

Gender, age, ethnicity, and race are collected as demographics and are exploratory
registration_responses.sample: N=1000 participants from MTurk. Due to the data collection process on Amazon's Mechanical Turk, it is possible that we will collect slightly more than 1000; then with exclusions (see previous section) we may have a slightly smaller sample.
registration_responses.analyses:
We will regress intention to voice onto time, condition, and an interaction between time and condition using a multilevel model with repeated measures.
We will use an independent sample t-test to compare amplification and control conditions at Time 2
registration_responses.outliers: We will delete data from any duplicate IP addresses and any duplicate worker IDs.

registration_responses.conditions: Participants will be randomly assigned to either the amplification or control condition.
registration_responses.hypothesis: Can amplification increase intention to voice in a group with uncivil interactions?

attributes.title: The social facilitation effect induced by camera exposure on the behavior and physiological reactions of adolescent freestyle snowboarders: a preregistered within-subject experimental study

summary.value:
Snowboarding is a very popular winter sport in North America. Despite the positive health outcomes of sports participation, injuries are likely to occur while snowboarding. For more than a decade, action cameras (e.g., GoPro) have been widely accessible in the context of snowsports. The impact of such technologies in a sport-related context is little explored but, according to the scientific literature, there are reasons to believe that it could affect the safety of users. The aim of this report is to describe our methods regarding a within-subject experimental design where the effect of camera exposure on the risk-taking behavior of high school freestyle snowboarders will be examined in a real-world setting. In a sport-related context, data on the physiological responses of teenagers such as the heart rate, heart rate variability, and respiratory rate will also be collected in two experimental conditions: with and without camera. These will measure the social stress induced by camera use. Participants will be compared to themselves in terms of risk-taking behavior and physiological responses. Descriptive analyzes will be done first to describe the sample collected. The effect of the experimental conditions on risk taking and physiological activation will be verified by covariance analyzes for repeated measures (mixed models) using as independent variables nested in the individual time and the experimental conditions. The link between personality traits and the behaviors of freestyle snowboarders on slopes will be assessed through correlational analyzes.

*Document for a preregistration:
The methods regarding our within-subject experimental design are described in the attached report (PDF file).

registration_responses.summary:
Snowboarding is a very popular winter sport in North America. Despite the positive health outcomes of sports participation, injuries are likely to occur while snowboarding. For more than a decade, action cameras (e.g., GoPro) have been widely accessible in the context of snowsports. The impact of such technologies in a sport-related context is little explored but, according to the scientific literature, there are reasons to believe that it could affect the safety of users. The aim of this report is to describe our methods regarding a within-subject experimental design where the effect of camera exposure on the risk-taking behavior of high school freestyle snowboarders will be examined in a real-world setting. In a sport-related context, data on the physiological responses of teenagers such as the heart rate, heart rate variability, and respiratory rate will also be collected in two experimental conditions: with and without camera. These will measure the social stress induced by camera use. Participants will be compared to themselves in terms of risk-taking behavior and physiological responses. Descriptive analyzes will be done first to describe the sample collected. The effect of the experimental conditions on risk taking and physiological activation will be verified by covariance analyzes for repeated measures (mixed models) using as independent variables nested in the individual time and the experimental conditions. The link between personality traits and the behaviors of freestyle snowboarders on slopes will be assessed through correlational analyzes.

*Document for a preregistration:
The methods regarding our within-subject experimental design are described in the attached report (PDF file).

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Replication of: Self-control translates environmental attitudes into behavior (Berger, Wyss, Study 1, Mturk, 2019).

other.value: Replication of: Self-control translates environmental attitudes into behavior (Berger, Wyss, Study 1, Mturk, 2019).

sample.value: A total of 600 HITS are created on Amazon Mechanical Turk. The sample size has been decided due to budgetary restrictions. This is a replication study using a larger sample of the previously gathered data with 200 participants.

analyses.value: We will run a panel probit regression to estimate our main hypothesis. The trials create a 25-times repeated measure with accept/forego bonus as the dependent variable in each trial. The independent variables of the model are participants NEP-R scores, their trait self-control scores, and the interaction thereof.

outliers.value: We will exclude all participants who fail to correctly answer both of the two control questions. Additionally, we will exclude participants who fail to make at least 70% (18/25) of the decisions in the trials (decisions are timed and the trial automatically proceeds after 15 seconds).

dependent.value: The dependent variable consists of 25 decisions made by the participants. In each decision, the participant faces a trade-off between a financial reward (i.e., a bonus-opportunity on Mturk) that comes with actual CO2 emissions and foregoing the reward while avoiding the emission. The trials vary in bonus height and amount of CO2 emissions (5x5, fully crossed).

conditions.value: The main research question is correlational (effect of NEP-R moderated by self-control on choices), but the trials are a fully crossed 5x5 design enabling us to estimate the effect of CO2 emissions and bonus height on choices. Varying the level of CO2 emissions and bonus height enables us to create a measure of decision conlict (emissions per cent bonus) that will serve as an independent variable.

hypothesis.value:
The main research question is whether trait self-control (measured by the BSCS, Tangney et al.) moderates the effect of environmental attitudes (measured by NEP-R) on pro-environmental choices. 
The main hypothesis is that high values of self-control increase the effect of NEP-R on sustainable decision-making.
